abstract.p: The rapid protein adsorption on a material surface causes blood coagulation, platelet activation, and complement system activation, which poses a risk for failure of cardiovascular devices. In this study, a chemically hydroxylated titanium surface was aminosilanized and covalently grafted with poly(ethylene glycol). The reaction conditions on the grafted quantity were studied by the respective amine and carboxyl densities. The blood compatibility of the PEGylated surfaces with different poly(ethylene glycol) densities and chain lengths was evaluated; the PEGylated surfaces with higher grafted density and longer chain length had less fibrinogen adsorption, less fibrinogen γ-chain exposed, less adherent platelets, and lower activation of the adherent platelets. In addition to the influence on blood, the longer chain PEGylated surfaces resisted, not only smooth muscle cell attachment and proliferation, but also macrophage attachment and death. This method is a good candidate for improving cardiovascular implant surfaces.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the main cause of death in seven million people worldwide annually and represents 12% of all global deaths. Many cardiovascular and other blood contacting biomedical devices have been applied, such as stents, vascular grafts, artificial heart valves, and blood pumps, and contribute significantly to the quality and effectiveness of the health-care system. However, the contact between artificial materials and body fluids induces a variety of biological responses, including adsorption of proteins and activation of complement and coagulation systems. The interaction of plasma proteins with artificial materials initiates a series of events, which may lead to thrombus formation or induce inflammatory responses, that could cause failure of the whole treatment. Surface modification with antithrombotic agents has been frequently applied to reduce coagulation activation.1–3 However, the prevention of nonspecific adsorption of blood proteins is desirable to improve surface characteristics and enhance the biocompatibility of implanted biomedical materials.

Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) is a nontoxic and nonimmunogenic polymer that is soluble in aqueous solvents, as well as many organic solvents. It has been used at the interface of body fluids and artificial materials and has promising thrombus-resistant behavior in contact with blood.4 The hydrophilicity, high mobility, large excluded volume, and steric hindrance effects contribute to the protein resistance of surface-immobilized PEG.5 Previous studies indicate that, the ability to resist protein adsorption is proportional to the polymer chain length and surface density.6 PEG has been immobilized onto material surfaces via self-assembly,7 physical adsorption,8,9 formation of surface physical interpenetrating networks,10 or covalent grafting.11 Covalent bonding of PEG to substrates is the most effective way to prepare a stable, PEG-modified surface. However, direct coupling requires functional groups or coupling agents on the substrate surface with which a derivatized PEG can react. The interfacial coupling reaction limited the applicability of the technique to certain substrate materials.

The commonly applied metals have low chemical reactivity, generally preventing covalent functionalization. Silane coupling agents have been used to bond biomolecules onto different materials that have hydroxyl groups on their surface.12 An amine-terminated silane with good biocompatibility has been successfully introduced for biomedical device treatment (BPS215; Thoratec Corporation [(Pleasanton, CA, USA]).13 The primary amie groups allow chemical grafting by conventional carbodiimide chemistry.14

Titanium (Ti) and titanium alloys have desirable properties, such as relatively low modulus, good fatigue strength, formability, and corrosion resistance. Therefore, they are used in biomedical devices and components, especially as hard-tissue replacements as well as in cardiac and cardiovascular applications. However, due to the insufficient blood compatibility, titanium and its alloys do not meet all clinical requirements in cardiac and cardiovascular applications.

PEG-modified surfaces are known to resist protein adsorption and platelet adhesion,15,16 but the effect of surface PEGylation on platelet adhesion and activation is not well known. In the present study, PEGylated titanium surfaces with different chain lengths and chain densities were prepared as shown in Figure 1, and their blood compatibility and cytocompatibility were also studied.

caption.p: Reaction scheme for the immobilization of PEG molecules on the titanium surface.

sec.p: We found that higher chain density and longer chain length of the PEG on the surface allowed less fibrinogen adsorption, less fibrinogen γ-chain exposure, less platelet adhesion, and less platelet activation. In addition, the longer chain PEGylated surfaces resisted smooth muscle cell (SMC) attachment and proliferation as well as prevented macrophage attachment and death, thus reducing the risk of restenosis in the case of application on vascular stents.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Commercial pure titanium (cpTi) was purchased from Baoji Non-ferrous Metal Co., Ltd. (Baoji, Shanxi, China). The 3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyltrimethoxysilane, N-(3-dimethyl-aminopropyl)-N′-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC), N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS), acid orange II (AO II), toluidine blue O (TBO), and Triton X-100 were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). PEG–disuccinate (PEG–diacid) and goat antihuman fibrinogen IgG horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugated antibody were purchased from Biomatrik Inc. (Jiaxing, Zhejiang, China), and Beijing Biosynthesis Biotechnology Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China), respectively. Monoclonal mouse antihuman fibrinogen γ-chain, monoclonal sheep antimouse IgG HRP conjugated antibody, monoclonal mouse antihuman antibody against P-selectin, and monoclonal sheep antimouse IgG fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) conjugated antibody were purchased from BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA. Acridine orange (AO) and ethidium bromide (EB) were purchased from Bio Basic Inc., Shanghai, China. All the other reagents used in the experiments were of the highest analytical purity (>99.9%).

sec.title: Silanization
sec.p: The reactions were carried out as shown in Figure 1. Pieces of titanium (1 × 1 × 0.2 cm3) were polished to a mirror-like finish. The specimens were ultrasonically cleaned in a detergent solution, then in acetone, then in ethanol, and finally in deionized water. The cleaned specimens were soaked in 5 M NaOH solution at 60°C for 24 h, followed by deionized water at 80°C for 8 h (Figure 1(a)),1 and, subsequently, were immersed in a 5 wt% solution of 3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyltrimethoxysilane in anhydrous toluene. At reaction times, 3, 6, 9, and 12 h, samples, denoted as TiOH–Sil (Figure 1(b)), were removed, sonicated, and rinsed, consecutively, with toluene, ethanol, and water to remove ungrafted material from the surface.

sec.title: PEG immobilization
sec.p: The TiOH–Sil specimens were immersed in the PEG–disuccinate mixture solutions, by adding 100 mg of 2-morpholinoethane sulfonic acid (MES), 20 mg of EDC, and 15 mg of NHS in 10 mL of deionized water at pH 5. The reaction was carried out for 4 h at room temperature (RT), 37°C, and then for 8 h at 60°C. The TiOH–Sil–PEG (or Ti–S–P) product was sonicated in water to remove nongrafted moieties on the surface (Figure 1(c)). This process with PEG–disuccinate mixture solutions was carried out in three different concentrations (1, 10, and 100 mg mL−1) with PEG of molecular weights (MWs) 600, 1000, 2000, or 4000.

sec.title: Fourier transform infrared spectra
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR; ST-IR20SX; Nicolet Co., Ltd., Madison, WI, USA) spectra were recorded in diffuse reflectance (DR) mode. FTIR spectra in the range 4000–400 cm−1 were recorded in order to investigate the nature of the chemical bonds formed.

sec.title: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
sec.p: The surface composition of the samples was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PerkinElmer 16PC [Eden Prairie, MN, USA]) with an Al K-alpha X-ray source (1486.6 eV photons). A wide-scan survey spectrum over a binding energy (BE) range of 0–1400 eV was recorded at pass energy of 80 eV for estimation of the chemical elemental composition and 10 eV for highly resolved C1s peaks. The system was calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. All spectra were recorded at a take-off angle of 15°. The maximum information depth of the XPS method is not more than 10 nm. Spectrum background was subtracted according to the Shirley method. The parameters of the component peak fitting were their BE, height, full width at half maximum, and the Gaussian–Lorentzian ratio.

sec.title: Quantification of amine groups
sec.p: Density of surface amine groups (primary, secondary, and ternary) of samples was measured using a modified AO II assay.17 Samples were immersed into a 500 µmol L−1 AO II solution dissolved in water at pH 3 (adjusted with HCl). After shaking at least for 12 h at RT, samples were washed five times with dilute HCl. In order to release the adsorbed AO II, they were shaken for 30 min at RT in water at pH 12 (adjusted with NaOH). The AO II concentration of the solution was colorimetrically determined with an optical spectrometer at 485 nm with a microplate photometer (µQuant, BioTek, Winooski, VT, USA). The amount of surface-grafted amine groups was then calculated from a calibration curve generated with AO II solutions of known concentrations and under the assumption that AO II was complexed to equivalent moles of amine groups.

sec.title: Quantification of carboxyl groups
sec.p: Density of surface carboxyl groups of samples was measured using a modified TBO assay.18 In brief, samples were immersed in 500 µmol L−1 TBO solution (adjusted to pH 10 with NaOH) at RT for 3 h. Excess dye was rinsed off with pH 10 sodium hydroxide solution five times and transferred to 50% acetic acid solution to desorb the complexed dye. After 30 min, the concentrations of the desorbed dye were measured at 633 nm in a microplate photometer. The amount of surface-grafted carboxyl groups was then calculated from a calibration curve generated with TBO solutions of known concentrations and under the assumption that TBO was complexed to equivalent moles of carboxyl groups.

sec.title: Water contact angle
sec.p: Water contact angle (WCA) analysis was performed with DSA100 drop-shape analysis system (DSA100, KRÜSS GmbH, Hamburg, Germany) using double-distilled water. Five samples were measured for each group, and two individual measurements were made for each sample. The measurements were performed at RT.

sec.title: Biological evaluation of functionalized titanium surfaces
In vitro testing of blood compatibility
Quantification of adsorbed fibrinogen on the material surface
sec.p: Fibrinogen on the material surface was measured by direct immunochemistry.19 The platelet-poor plasma (PPP) was prepared by centrifuging (3000 r min−1, 15 min) fresh human whole blood containing 3.8 wt% citric acid solution (Na3C6O5H7.5H2O; blood: citric acid = 9:1) obtained from healthy volunteers after informed consent, and then 50 µL of fresh PPP was placed onto the sample surface and kept in contact with the surface for 30 min at 37°C.

After incubation, the samples were gently rinsed in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and then 2 mL of 1% sheep serum was added into each well and incubated for 30 min at 37°C to block nonspecific adsorption; 50 µL of goat antihuman fibrinogen IgG HRP conjugated antibody (1:250) was added onto the sample surfaces, incubated for 30 min at 37°C, and subsequently washed three times with PBS for 5 min; then 140 µL of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) chromogenic solution was added into the well containing the samples, and allowed to react for 5 min; subsequently, 40 µL of 2 M H2SO4 was added to stop the reaction; and finally, 150 µL of the reacting solution was transferred into a 96-well plate. The absorbance was measured at 452 nm and calibrated to the antibody amount using a standard curve of defined antibody concentrations. The data were normalized to the fibrinogen adsorption to bare Ti as 100%.

sec.title: Quantification of fibrinogen-exposed γ-chain on the material surface
sec.p: The conformational changes by fibrinogen, that is, exposure of γ-chain, play a critical role in fibrin cross-linking, clot formation, and interactions with other molecules.20 The amount of exposed γ-chain on the material surfaces was measured by indirect immunochemistry. The procedure was the same as the procedure used for quantification of adsorbed fibrinogen with 50 µL of monoclonal mouse antihuman fibrinogen γ-chain antibody (the first antibody; 1:250) was added to the sample surfaces, incubated for 2 h at 37°C, and subsequently washed three times with PBS for 5 min. The monoclonal sheep antimouse IgG HRP conjugated antibody (the second antibody; 1:100) was added to the surface of the samples, incubated for 1 h at 37°C, and subsequently washed with PBS for 5 min. TMB chromogenic solution (140 µL) was added into the well containing the samples, and reacted for 5 min; subsequently, 40 µL of 2 M H2SO4 was added to stop the reaction. The reaction solution (150 µL) was transferred to a new 96-well plate. The absorbance was measured at 452 nm and calibrated to the antibody amount using a standard curve of defined antibody concentrations. The data are normalized to the fibrinogen exposing γ-chain to bare Ti as 100%.

sec.title: Platelet adhesion testing
sec.p: The platelet-rich plasma (PRP) was prepared by centrifuging (1500 r min−1, 15 min) fresh human whole blood containing 3.8 wt% citric acid solution (blood: citric acid = 9:1) obtained from healthy volunteers after informed consent. After immersing into 400 µL of fresh PRP for 2 h at 37°C, the samples were gently rinsed in PBS to remove loosely adherent platelets from the surface and then they were prepared for subsequent scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis or lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test.

The samples were fixed by 0.2% glutaraldehyde in PBS for 1 h and 0.5% glutaraldehyde in PBS for 12 h. Then, the samples were washed with PBS and dehydrated in a series of increasing ethanol concentrations, then critical point dried and sputter coated with gold for observation using SEM.

The number of adherent platelets was quantified by determining the LDH release after lysis of the cells. A photospectrometric assay based on kinetic determination of the LDH activity was applied. The adherent platelets were lysed by the addition of 40 µL of 0.1% Triton X-100 to the sample. After 5 min of incubation at RT, 25 µL of each lysate was collected and mixed with 200 µL mixture solution consisted of 297 µL of 10 mg mL−1 reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH), 187 µL of 10 mg mL−1 pyruvate and 10 mL of tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane buffer, pH 7.2. The LDH activity in the lysate was then determined by recording the change in absorbance at 340 nm using a microplate photometer. This activity was rated to a lysate of the platelets in the initial PRP in order to quantify the relative number of platelets on each sample.

sec.title: Platelet activation
sec.p: Surface-induced platelet activation was measured by immunofluorescence method for P-selectin that is expressed on the surface of activated platelets. The procedure was as follows: (a) samples with adhered platelets were fixed with 2.5% glutaraldehyde in PBS for 2 h and subsequently washed with PBS for 5 min; (b) 2 mL of 1% sheep serum was added into each well and incubated for 5 min at 37°C to block nonspecific adsorption; (c) 50 µL of monoclonal mouse antihuman antibody against P-selectin (1:100; the first antibody) was added onto the sample surfaces, incubated for 2 h at 37°C, and subsequently washed three times with PBS for 5 min; (d) monoclonal sheep antimouse IgG FITC conjugated antibody (the second antibody; 1:100) was added to the surface of the samples, incubated for 1 h at 37°C, and subsequently washed with PBS for 5 min three times; and (e) the samples were immediately examined with fluorescence microscope with the binning 4 × 4 and the exposure of 15 s (Leica DMRX polarization microscope; Solms, Germany).

sec.title: In vitro testing of SMCs compatibility
Isolation and culture of SMCs
sec.p: Human umbilical artery SMCs were isolated from newborn umbilical cord as described previously.21 Cells in passage 2–5 were used. The SMCs were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM; Gibco BRL, Gaithersburg, MD, USA) containing 10% newborn calf serum, penicillin (100 U mL−1), and streptomycin sulfate (100 U mL−1) at 37°C under 5% CO2. Cells were fed with fresh medium every third day and subcultured regularly after the adhered cells reached about 80% confluence.

sec.title: Cell attachment in vitro
sec.p: The samples were placed into the wells of a 24-well flat-bottomed plate (Corning Costar, Tewksbury, MA, USA). One milliliter of SMC suspension in DMEM medium containing 10% new fetal calf serum at a density of 5 × 104 mL−1 were seeded and allowed to attach in an orbital shaker incubator at 80 r min−1 and 37°C for 1d and 2d. Cell attachment was determined by the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay: At the end of the incubation, the samples were washed with PBS to remove nonadherent cells, then put into new wells with 300 µL fresh medium and 30 µL of thiazolyl blue tetrazolium bromide (5 mg mL−1 in PBS). After 3 h of incubation in a cell incubator (37°C, 5% CO2), the media were withdrawn and the cells were incubated with 300 mL dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) for further 30 min at 37°C. One hundred and fifty microliter of DMSO solutions of the different samples was analyzed for absorbance at 490 nm in a microplate reader.

sec.title: In vitro testing of macrophages compatibility
Macrophages culture in vitro
sec.p: The murine macrophage cell line RAW264.7 was cultured in DMEM medium containing 10% new fetal calf serum in tissue culture polystyrene flasks. Cells were routinely detached by mechanical force and subsequently split in a ratio of 1:5.

sec.title: Attachment of macrophages and measurement of cell death
sec.p: The samples with different surfaces were placed into the wells of a 24-well flat-bottomed plate (Corning Costar). One milliliter of macrophage suspension in DMEM medium containing 10% new fetal calf serum at a density of 1 × 105 mL−1 were seeded and allowed to attach in an orbital shaker incubator at 80 r min−1 and 37°C for 8 h. At the end of the incubation, the samples were washed with PBS to remove nonadherent cells, and then put into new wells with 300 µL fresh medium. After 0.5 h of incubation in a cell incubator (37°C, 5% CO2), cells were stained by AO/EB staining. We started the staining procedure by adding 8 µL of AO/EB (1:1; the dye mixture solution for the EB/AO staining was 100 µg mL−1 AO and 100 µg mL−1 EB in PBS) for each well, after which the medium was gently mixed and incubated for 10 min at 37°C. Then, the effect was observed by using optical microscope, which showed viable cells (green) and nonviable cells (red).22 This method combines the differential uptake of fluorescent DNA-binding dyes AO and EB and the morphological aspect of chromatin condensation in the stained nucleus, allowing one to distinguish between viable and nonviable cells. The AO is taken up by both viable and nonviable cells and emits green fluorescence, as a result of intercalation into double-stranded nucleic acids (mainly DNA). The EB is only taken up by nonviable cells and emits red fluorescence by intercalation into DNA.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: All experiments were performed at least three independent times. All data were compared with one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests to evaluate statistical significance using SPSS software. Within the ANOVA analysis, Tukey’s multiple comparison test was performed to find significant differences between pairs. Probability values less than 0.01 was considered statistically significant. In Figures 4 to 6 and 8, only the significances between the groups were indicated. A statistically significant difference (p < 0.01) was denoted with “**.”

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: A chemically hydroxylated titanium surface was aminosilanized and covalently grafted with PEG. The reaction conditions on the grafted quantity were studied by the respective amine and carboxyl densities. The FTIR spectra of the different surfaces at various stages of surface functionalization are shown in Figure 2. The spectrum of the material treated with NaOH (TiOH) is the broad, weak band at 3375 cm−1 attributed to hydroxyl groups, which facilitated the binding of the aminosilane as coupling agent. A previous study has demonstrated the requirement of hydroxyl groups on the surface for silanization, showing a dependency of immobilized molecules of the concentration of hydroxyl groups.23 The broader, stronger band at 3375–3235 cm−1 of the aminosilanized surface is attributed to hydroxyl groups coming from methoxysilyl group hydrolysis and amino groups coming from 3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyltrimethoxysilane. The new bands at 2918 cm−1 correspond to C–H stretching and at 2848 cm−1 correspond to NH2 group and vibrational bands at 1651 and 1030 cm−1 correspond to Si–O, indicating that the aminosilane coupling agent was immobilized on the titanium surface. During PEG immobilization, the methoxysilyl group hydrolysis and the condensation reaction between NH2 and COOH led to weakening of peaks at 1450 and 1420 cm−1, which contribute to CH3-deformation from methoxy group and primary amide III, respectively. In the IR spectra of the PEGylated surface, the presence of new bands at 1080 cm−1, corresponding to stretching of the C–O–C, indicate that PEG was immobilized onto the surface of titanium.

caption.p: The DR–FTIR spectra of different surfaces.
DR: diffuse reflectance; FTIR: Fourier transform infrared.

sec.p: The chemical composition of the surfaces at various stages of surface functionalization was determined by XPS. The XPS wide-scan spectra of the aminosilanized surface and the PEGylated surface are shown in Figure 3(a). In the wide-scan spectrum of the TiOH–Sil, the presence of N and Si indicate that 3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyltrimethoxysilane was successfully immobilized onto the surface of titanium. After PEG immobilization, Ti2p peak disappeared, N1s and Si peaks decreased, indicating the existence of PEG. From the high-resolution spectra of element N (Figure 3(b)), the shift of N1s centroid from ~399.1 to ~399.9 eV indicated a chemical change on the titanium surface from the amine-type nitrogen (399.1 eV) to the amide-type nitrogen (399.9 eV)24 due to grafting reaction of surface amino groups on TiOH–Sil.

caption.p: (a) The XPS spectra are a wide scan of the TiOH–Sil and TiOH–Sil–PEG, (b) the high-resolution spectra are the TiOH–Sil and TiOH–Sil–PEG nitrogen, (c) the high-resolution spectra are C1s for the TiOH–Sil, and (d) the high-resolution spectra are C1s for the TiOH–Sil–PEG.
XPS: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy; PEG: poly(ethylene glycol).

sec.p: The element C, Figure 3(c) and (d), is represented by the high-resolution C1s spectra for the TiOH–Sil and TiOH–Sil–PEG. The C1s spectrum for TiOH–Sil (Figure 3(c)) was curve-fitted with three peak components, with BEs at 284.6 eV for the C–C/C–H/C–Si species, 285.5 eV for the C–C/C–H species, and 286.5 eV for the C–O/C–N species.25 The C1s spectrum for TiOH–Sil–PEG (Figure 3(d)) can be curve-fitted with four peak components, with BEs at 284.5 eV for the C–C/C–H/C–Si species, 285.4 eV for the C–C/C–H species, 286.2 eV for the C–O/C–N/C–O–C species, and 287.4 eV for the C=O species.26 The C–O–C and C═O peaks represent PEG–diacid.

sec.title: Quantification of amine groups
sec.p: The quantitative amine concentration on the surface was obtained by labeling with AO II. Spectrometric analysis of the stained samples (Figure 4) indicated that the amine concentration with reaction time did not change significantly. The highest amine concentration was 15.2 ± 2.2 nmol cm−2 obtained at 6 h (n = 5).

caption.p: Quantification of amine groups measuring by Acid Orange II method.

sec.title: Quantification of PEG density
sec.p: Toluidine blue method was used to determine the amount of carboxyl groups on the PEGylated surface. Light scattering experiments unambiguously revealed that PEG does not aggregate in water27 and infrared spectroscopy proved formation of the unfolding helical structure of PEG in water solvent.28,29 So, it was expected that the PEG–disuccinate bonds with one carboxyl end to the aminosilanized surface and another carboxyl end would be exposed, so the amount of carboxyl measuring by the toluidine blue method represents the grafted amount of PEG on the surface. The effects of solution concentration (Figure 5(a)), reaction temperature, and reaction time (Figure 5(b)) on the grafted amount of PEG600 were measured. With the concentration of PEG600 solution increasing from 1 to 10 mg mL−1, the grafted amount increased from 1.8 ± 0.3 to 3.8 ± 0.5 chains/nm2 (Figure 5(a)). With the concentration increasing from 10 to 100 mg mL−1, the grafted amount of PEG increased from 3.8 ± 0.5 to 4.5 ± 0.5 chains/nm2(Figure 5(a)), but lower than the estimated upper limit of 5.8 chains/nm2 for the fully extended PEG chains.30 Because of efficiency and economical factors, the PEG solution concentration of 10 mg mL−1 was adopted. The effect of reaction temperature on the PEG grafted, amount as shown in Figure 5(b), was far greater than effect of reaction time. When reaction temperature was below 60°C, the PEG graft increased with temperature. At RT and 37°C, the grafted amount increased with reaction time within 8 h. At 60°C, the PEG graft in 4 h was higher than that in 8 h. The PEG graft increased with reaction time and/or solution concentration because of the increased probability of coupling reactions between PEG chains and reactive pinning sites on the surface. Under elevating temperature, PEG undergoes a reversible phase change due to disruption of the hydration shell surrounding the PEG chains, which results in reduced interchain repulsion distances and association between PEG molecules.26 As a consequence, the PEG chains are no longer well solvated as individual random coils. As the hydrodynamic volume of individual chains is much reduced, denser packing of grafted chains is possible if sufficiently dense reactive pinning sites are available on the surface.26 However, higher temperatures (60°C) and longer time (8 h) did not provide the most grafted PEG. It seems that at higher temperatures, the rate of hydrolysis of the silanized layer is faster in the acidic solution,31 thus more PEG was grafted after 4 h than after 8 h at high temperatures. The relationship between the graft density and MW, as shown in Figure 5(c), that the short chain could obtain a higher grafting density in the same reaction condition, is probably due to the increase in steric hindrance associated with the incorporation of longer chains into the developing layer.30 Based on these results, the PEG concentration, PEG MW, reaction temperature, and reaction time could potentially regulate the amount of grafted PEG. However, the reaction temperature and concentration are more sensitive to regulate the amount of PEG grafted than the other factors.

caption.p: Quantification of carboxyl groups measuring by toluidine blue method. These results suggest that the (a) PEG concentration, (b) reaction temperature and reaction time, and (c) PEG molecular weight could regulate the grafted amount of PEG on the surface. Reaction temperature and solution concentration are the most sensitive in all these factors.
PEG: poly(ethylene glycol).

sec.title: WCA
sec.p: Previous theoretical and experimental approaches using PEGylated surfaces to resist protein adsorption indicate that the nonfouling character of PEG-modified surfaces is proportional to the PEG chain length and surface density.6 Platelet and cell resistance of PEGylated surfaces has been reported;15,16 however, a detailed relationship between blood compatibility and PEG chain length and surface density has not been reported. To evaluate the effect of the grafted density and MW of PEG on the blood compatibility, the PEG600 and PEG4000 surfaces with low chain density (~0.5 chains/nm2) and high chain density (~3 chains/nm2) were prepared. The measurement of WCA is well-known as a useful technique to investigate the surface characteristics. WCA of different surfaces is shown in Figure 6. Compared with Ti, the WCA of surface treatment with NaOH decreased significantly. Aminosilanized surface was hydrophobic. Relative to aminosilanized surface, the WCA of the low-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P600–L and Ti–S–P4000–L) did not change significantly; meanwhile, the WCA of the high-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P600–H and Ti–S–P4000–H) decreased significantly.

caption.p: Water contact angle with different surfaces.

sec.p: It seems that grafted PEG chains can appear either as a mushroom conformation (Figure 7(a) and (c)) or a brush conformation (Figure 7(e) and (g)).32 The mushroom conformation occurs when the graft separation distance (d) is greater than the radius of gyration (Rg) of the polymer chains, and when d < Rg, the brush conformation is induced. During the process of measurement of WCA, the dried surfaces with low PEG chain density are not in the mushroom conformation but rather in the collapsed state (Figure 7(b) and (d)), which exposes the underlying substrate,30,32 which is hydrophobic. Whether PEG is in the brush or in the collapsed conformation, with increasing PEG chain density, the surfaces were completely covered with PEG making the surfaces hydrophilic.

caption.p: Schematic representation of various PEG coating structures and the PEGylated surface: (a) PEG grafted to Ti–S–P600–L is the mushroom conformation; (b) in dry conditions, PEG grafted to Ti–S–P600–L is in the collapsed state; (c) PEG grafted to Ti–S–P4000–L is the mushroom conformation; (d) in dry conditions, PEG grafted to Ti–S–P4000–L is in the collapsed state; (e) PEG grafted to Ti–S–P600–H is the brush conformation; (f) in dry conditions, PEG grafted to Ti–S–P600–H is in the collapsed state; (g) PEG grafted to Ti–S–P4000–H is the brush conformation; and (h) in dry conditions, PEG grafted to Ti–S–P4000–H is in the collapsed state.
PEG: poly(ethylene glycol).

sec.title: Quantification of adsorbed fibrinogen on the surfaces
sec.p: When a cardiovascular and other blood contacting biomedical device is implanted in the human body, the adsorption of plasma proteins to the surface of the implant is one of the first events that happens, which subsequently influences the cellular response to the biomedical device. Generally, cells do not have receptors that are able to recognize synthetic materials, but they adhere to the surface of the implant via interactions with bioactive sites presented by the layer of adsorbed proteins.

Fibrinogen, one of the most important proteins in the blood coagulation, has several cell adhesion and protein interaction domains. The data of the fibrinogen adsorption on the various surfaces, normalized to the amount on titanium, are shown in Figure 8(a). Compared to Ti, the amount of fibrinogen adsorption on other surfaces decreased. Fibrinogen adsorption increased in the order: TiOH–Sil < Ti–S–P4000–H < Ti–S–P600–H < Ti–S–P4000–L < Ti–S–P600–L < Ti. The aminosilanized titanium surface resisted fibrinogen adsorption. One explanation is that albumin has more negatively charged amine residues on their surface than fibrinogen. This would cause the positively charged amine surface (surface pK 8.9) to have a stronger electrostatic interaction with albumin than fibrinogen, thus adsorption of albumin and other acidic proteins would exceed the fibrinogen adsorption onto the aminosilanized surface.33 The fibrinogen adsorption was reduced on the various PEGylated surface by ~50%–75% compared to the titanium surface.

caption.p: Relative amount of (a) fibrinogen, (b) fibrinogen-exposed γ-chain, and (c) platelets on the material surface compared with Ti (n = 5).

sec.p: With the same PEG chain density, the long-chain surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–L and Ti–S–P4000–H) resisted fibrinogen adsorption more effectively than the short-chain surfaces (Ti–S–P600–L and Ti–S–P600–H). This is in good agreement with the data that antifouling character of PEG-modified surfaces is proportional to the PEG chain length in the range up to ~103.34 With the same PEG MW, the high-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–H and Ti–S–P600–H) resisted fibrinogen adsorption more effectively than the low-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–L and Ti–S–P600–L). Compared with the short-chain surfaces and the low-chain-density surfaces, the long-chain surfaces and the high-chain-density surfaces could create more effective steric hindrance effects, which contribute to the ability of surface-immobilized PEG to resist fibrinogen adsorption. Ellipsometry and direct detection of radio-labeled proteins have been used to determine the amount of protein adsorbed on the surfaces.30,35 The radioactive methods determine the absolute amounts of protein on the surface, while the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) determines the protein adsorbed on the topmost surface. However, it is known that only the bioactive sites of the adsorbed protein on synthetic material’s topmost surfaces can be recognized by cells and platelets. In addition, due to the roughness of the aminosilanized titanium surfaces (supplement data), ellipsometry is not useful to determine the amount of adsorbed fibrinogen.

sec.title: Quantification of conformational change of fibrinogen on the surfaces
sec.p: The fibrinogen molecules are folded in plasma with little γ-chain exposure; however, most of them will be conformationally changed with γ-chain exposure, after adsorption on a foreign surface. The exposure of the encrypted γ-chain allows fibrinogen to bind to the GPIIb/IIIa integrin receptor on platelet membrane and further cause the adhesion and aggregation of platelets.20,36 The relative amount of fibrinogen with exposed γ-chain on the different surfaces is shown in Figure 8(b). The relative amount of denatured fibrinogen, exposing γ-chain, increased in the order: Ti–S–P4000–H < Ti–S–P4000–L < Ti–S–P600–H < Ti–S–P600–L < TiOH–Sil < Ti. Compared with Ti, the amount of exposed γ-chain on the PEGylated surfaces decreased with the increased grafting density and MW. The long-chain surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–L and Ti–S–P4000–) or the high-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–H and Ti–S–P600–H) have less-denatured fibrinogen than the short-chain surface (Ti–S–P600–L and Ti–S–P600–H) or low-chain-density surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–L and Ti–S–P600–L). The flexibility of the PEG chains on the long-chain surfaces and the high-chain-density surfaces prevents the fibrinogen from being tightly absorbed, thus preventing conformation changes in dynamic condition, such as in a blood stream and in the PBS rinsing process.

The quantitative analysis of platelet adhesion on the different surfaces was performed, by determination of the LDH release after lysis of the adherent blood platelets. The adherent platelets on the PEGylated surfaces decreased with MW and chain density increase and were far less than that on the titanium surface (Figure 8(c)). The adherent platelets on Ti–S–P4000–H was less than that on Ti–S–P4000–L, but there was no significant difference for the high- and low-density grafted PEG600 surfaces. A speculation why the long-chain surfaces were more effective in resisting platelet adhesion than the short-chain surfaces is that the long-chain surfaces possess higher mobility and larger excluded volume than the short-chain surfaces, which lead to platelet desorption in dynamic conditions, such as in a blood stream and in the PBS rinsing process.

Thus, the ability to resist platelets adhesion increased with increases in the PEG chain density and MW. These results are in agreement with the amount of fibrinogen γ-chain exposure and not the amount of fibrinogen adsorption, indicating that the amount of fibrinogen-exposed γ-chain on the surface could predict platelet adhesion.20 Conventional thinking is that surfaces that adsorb the least amount of plasma proteins support less platelet adhesion, and thus, exhibit less surface thrombogenicity. However, other studies and our results indicate that the critical determinant of the hemocompatibility of a surface may actually be the conformational state of the adsorbed protein rather than the total amount of adsorbed protein on the surface.37

SEM imaging was preformed to visualize platelet adhesion and activation on the various surfaces (Figure 9). The number of adherent platelets on Ti was much greater than on the PEGylated surfaces. Long-chain surfaces (Ti–S–P4000–L and Ti–S–P4000–H) were more effective in preventing platelet adhesion than short-chain surfaces (Ti–S–P600–L and Ti–S–P600–H). The platelets on Ti–S–P4000–H were generally singular with the round shapes typical of an inactivated state; no pseudopodia or deformation was observed.

caption.p: SEM micrographs of platelets adhered on the different surfaces.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.p: The surface-induced platelet activation was probed by fluorescent staining for P-selectin (Figure 10); the activated platelets fluoresce green and were much less on the PEG surface than on the titanium surface. The Ti–S–P4000–H resisted platelet adhesion better than the other surfaces. Because the PEG600 surfaces did not improve the blood compatibility of the surface, it was not included in the following experiments.

caption.p: Representative P-selectin stain images showing activated platelets that conjugated with a fluorescent dye. There were less activated platelets on the PEGylated surface and the amount of activated platelets on the surface was decreased with increase of chain density and molecular weight of PEG.
PEG: poly(ethylene glycol).

sec.title: In vitro testing of SMCs compatibility
sec.p: When cardiovascular devices are placed in a blood environment, complications, such as thrombosis and restenosis, could lead to the failure of the treatment. Therefore, the antifouling character of PEG-modified surfaces on SMC attachment and proliferation was examined at 24 and 48 h by MTT assay (Figure 11). The SMC population on the PEGylated titanium was significantly lower than on the unmodified titanium and the aminosilanized titanium surface for all time points. The adhesion values of the unmodified titanium and adhesion on the aminosilanized titanium surface significantly increased over time, while they increased only a little on the PEGylated surfaces. Reason is that the high flexibility of the PEG chains prevents the deposition and organization of the cells’ extracellular matrix, which prevents cells spreading. The adsorption of high MW PEG/polylysine copolymers onto endovascular stents is known to reduce restenosis after implantation.38 In addition, the high-chain-density surface was less efficient to resist SMC attachment and proliferation compared with the low-chain-density surface. This may be attributed to the high COOH density, which to some extent promotes SMC attachment and proliferation.39

SMC: smooth muscle cell; MTT: 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide.

sec.title: In vitro testing of macrophages compatibility
sec.p: A pivotal factor to consider in the development of biomaterials and biomaterial coatings is the inflammatory responses to these materials. Macrophages orchestrate the activation of numerous cell types and are considered key regulators of the intensity and duration of inflammatory responses.40 Macrophages were stained, and the fluorescence was analyzed: green for viable cells and red for nonviable cells (Figure 12). The macrophage population on the PEGylated titanium was significantly lower than on the unmodified titanium and the aminosilanized titanium surface; however, the PEG4000 surfaces prevented macrophage death. The macrophage population and cell viability were similar on both the surfaces with different PEG density; no morphological differences were observed between macrophages cultured on the various surfaces. It has been reported that the grafted PEG inhibited the immune responses by lymphocytes and macrophages41 due to the flexibility of the PEG chains, which prevent the protein deposition, organization of the cells’ extracellular matrix and cell attachment. Fewer nonviable cells were found on the PEGylated surfaces than others, which could reduce local inflammation reaction and restenosis after implantation.

caption.p: Representative AO/EB stain images showing viable (green) and nonviable (red) macrophages attached to the different surfaces. There were less macrophages and lower ratio of nonviable macrophages on the PEGylated surfaces than other surfaces.
AO: acridine orange; EB: ethidium bromide; PEG: poly(ethylene glycol).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PEGylated titanium surfaces were prepared by aminosilylation and subsequent PEG immobilization. The PEG concentration, PEG chain length, reaction temperature, and time were used to regulate the grafted amount of PEG. The blood compatibility of the PEGylated surfaces was improved by increasing the graft density and MW. The PEG surfaces resist SMC and macrophage attachment prevented macrophage death. Therefore, this method is a viable candidate for further development of cardiovascular implant surface.
